settingsManager.sandbox.title: Sandbox & Security
settingsManager.sandbox.platformNote: Sandbox isolation is only available on macOS, Linux, and WSL2. Windows users should use alternative security measures.
settingsManager.sandbox.enableSandboxDes: Run bash commands in an isolated environment for security.
settingsManager.sandbox.autoAllowBashDes: Automatically approve bash commands when sandbox is enabled.
settingsManager.sandbox.allowUnsandboxed: Allow commands to request running outside the sandbox.
settingsManager.sandbox.excludedCommands: Commands that always run outside the sandbox (e.g., docker, git).
settingsManager.sandbox.allowLocalBindin: Allow sandboxed processes to bind to localhost ports (macOS only).
settingsManager.sandbox.allowedUnixSocke: Unix socket paths accessible from the sandbox.
settingsManager.permissions.defaultModeD: Controls how Claude Code handles permission requests for file edits and commands.
settingsManager.permissions.disableBypas: Prevent users from bypassing permission prompts with the 'dangerously accept all' option.
settingsManager.permissions.additionalDi: Grant Claude Code access to directories outside the current project.
settingsManager.analyzer.title: Settings Analyzer
settingsManager.analyzer.description: Understand where your Claude Code settings are stored and how they interact
settingsManager.analyzer.backupDescripti: Complete backup of all settings and MCP servers
settingsManager.analyzer.backupHint: Creates a unified preset containing all your settings and MCP servers
settingsManager.analyzer.whyComplex.titl: Why is Claude Code configuration complex?
settingsManager.analyzer.whyComplex.reas: Claude Code evolved rapidly to support various use cases: individual developers, team collaboration, and enterprise deployment. Each scope (user, project, local, managed) addresses different needs.
MCP servers have their own configuration files (.mcp.json, ~/.claude.json) separate from settings.json because they require different security models and version control strategies.
The priority system (Local > Project > User > Global) allows fine-grained control, but can be confusing when settings come from multiple files.
settingsManager.analyzer.priority.title: Priority Order
settingsManager.analyzer.priority.descri: Higher priority settings override lower ones. Local settings have the highest priority.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.title: MCP Server Locations
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.global: Global MCP servers available across all projects. Best for frequently used servers.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.project: Project-specific MCP servers. Shared with team via git. Must be confirmed before use.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.warning.tit: Important: MCP servers are NOT in settings.json
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.warning.des: MCP servers must be defined in ~/.claude.json (global) or .mcp.json (project). Servers in settings.json will not be recognized.
Claude Code requires configuration files inside each project directory. There's no centralized project management from ~/.claude.
Workaround: Use symlinks to share configurations across projects:
Link project config to centralized location
Alternatively, use presets to quickly apply common configurations to new projects.
Save your MCP server configurations as presets and quickly apply them to any project.
